title: Hereditary Hyperphosphatasia: A Rare Genetic Bone Disorder
short_description: Clinical overview of hereditary hyperphosphatasia, a rare autosomal recessive bone disorder causing progressive skeletal malformations in children, often referred to as juvenile Paget's disease.
long_description: This document provides a comprehensive clinical description of hereditary hyperphosphatasia, a rare genetic osteopathy that typically manifests during infancy or early childhood. The condition is characterized by progressive skeletal malformations, particularly affecting the long bones of the arms and legs, leading to walking difficulties, short stature, bone pain, fractures, and muscle weakness. The document explains the disorder's autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, its equal prevalence in males and females, and its increased occurrence in populations with consanguineous marriages. It details the diagnostic approach involving clinical evaluation, radiographic imaging, and biochemical testing showing elevated serum alkaline phosphatase levels. The text also clarifies the relationship between hereditary hyperphosphatasia and Paget's disease, noting their biochemical and radiographic similarities while emphasizing their distinct nature.
